turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Neurotoxicity.
turn.1: What are the main types of neurotoxic agents?
turn.2: The presence of neurocognitive deficits alone is not usually considered sufficient evidence of neurotoxicity, as many substances may impair neurocognitive performance without resulting in the death of neurons.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: This may be due to the direct action of the substance, with the impairment and neurocognitive deficits being temporary, and resolving when the substance is eliminated from the body.
turn.6: In some cases the level or exposure-time may be critical, with some substances only becoming neurotoxic in certain doses or time periods.
turn.7: What are some examples of the agents?
turn.8: Some of the most common naturally occurring brain toxins that lead to neurotoxicity as a result of excessive drug use are beta amyloid (Aβ), glutamate, dopamine, and oxygen radicals.
turn.10: When present in high concentrations, they can lead to neurotoxicity and death (apoptosis).
turn.11: What are some of the symptoms?
turn.12: Some of the symptoms that result from cell death include loss of motor control, cognitive deterioration and autonomic nervous system dysfunction.
